Northern Art: A Hidden Gem

The Hepworth Wakefield Gallery has been long-listed for the Art Fund prize 2012. Mary O'Connor visits and talks to its director, Simon Wallis, to find out why. (Thumbnail credit The Hepworth Gallery in Wakefiled)

Editor's Picks.

Recently, the Holocaust Memorial Day was celebrated nationally, a day to remember and honour those who died as part of the horrendous atrocities perpetrated by the Nazis

One Great Expectation

With the passing of Charles Dickens' bicentennial, Jonjo Lowe explores the author's works and their enduring relevance in the modern day (Thumbnail credit Charles Dickens)

Best Book

The term 'thriller' doesn't often go together with 'literary', but here the two collide in S. J. Watson's phenomenal debut novel

Editor's Favourites.

Having won the Costa Book Award of 2011, this is a book that will entrance those of you interested in the seamless intermingling of history and fiction

The Diary of Anne Frank

This is a respectful production of Anne Frank's Diary which draws strength from depicting the interplay between family relations, issues any family can relate to, creating a very real experience.

POSH

WARNING: Contains Spoilers!!

Fusion: The Story of Man

The resounding applause accompanying the encore of Fusion's 'Story of Man' is a testimony to the astonishing imagination and magnificent quality of performance realised by the cast and production team.

The Fantasist's Waltz

Welcome to the World of the Fantasist, where dreaming and reality are synonymous.

As Thyself

'As Thyself' was a powerful production, bringing us to the realisation that we all half swim, half sink in idealistic fantasies.

Norman Rea: Painterly Effluvia

Painterly Effluvia is the rather awe-inspiring title of the latest exhibition to grace the walls of the Norman Rea Gallery.

Into the Woods

It's not a flawless musical, but this was a brave, near flawless production, with an outstanding cast.

Twelfth Night

The confidence and comfort of the major characters onstage brought life and momentum to the play's hilarious twists of plot.

Omid Djalili

By James Bithell

Never lacking in energy, Djalili used topical humour, a wavering accent and intermittent belly dancing to set people rolling in the aisles.

Matilda The Musical

By James Bithell

This is a sensational theatrical adaption of Roald Dahl's cherished tale.

Dorian

Dorian is an innovative and enjoyable interpretation, which succeeds in elevating itself to the standard of professional theatre.

The Bigger Picture

David Hockney takes on the Yorkshire landscape with his iPad, Celia Scruby investigates

Derek Acorah: The Art of Unlocking the Mind

Derek Acorah contact the spirits of the dead and is one of the leading names in British mediumship.

Suggs: My Life Story

By James Bithell

An autobiography on-stage which is as full of madness as it is Madness.

Animal Farm

By James Bithell

This is a valiant effort to convey Orwell's sinister story, but at moments it lacked the vital darkness to communicate the horror of Animal Farm.

Pant Soc's Aladdin

By James Bithell

Combining all that a panto should, this is a corny yet predictably enjoyable production.

Vessels of Memory

By James Bithell

Not the Norma Rea's most enjoyable exhibition, but a thought provoking collaboration from two of Ireland's emerging artists.

Hamlet

This will quite possibly go down as one of the most memorable Shakespearean adaptations, starring Michael Sheen.

Stars in the Morning Sky

By James Bithell

A surreal but fantastic portrayal of the volatile nature of the lives of 1980`s Russia's lower class.

The York Family Robinson Pantomime

By James Bithell

Catch this piece of raw Christmas joy before its gone - in a glitter infused puff of smoke and wagon wheels.

The Trial

The performance erred too much on the side of the grotesque rather than the uncanny, but it is an interesting and highly watchable piece.

Butley

By James Bithell

Adam Alcock's remarkable production is both witty and refreshing, serving as a brilliant close to this term's season at the Drama Barn.

Metamorphosis

By James Bithell

There's nothing to unseat what develops into a highly competent, thought-provoking and watchable interpretation of Berkoff's Kafka.

Chris Addison

By James Bithell

Chris Addison's comedy to be as hit-and-miss as his persona was inconsistent.

Beyond the Barricade

By James Bithell

Why pay a bomb for west-end tickets when you can see all the best songs in one evening?
